content.raw: I think the difference between an email to ros-users and using the ros package pipeline is that here you're making a pull request to a repository for which OSRF owns the copyright. I would interpret that differently than packaging software, for which you would retain copyright.
content.html: I think the difference between an email to ros-users and using the ros package pipeline is that here you're making a pull request to a repository for which OSRF owns the copyright. I would interpret that differently than packaging software, for which you would retain copyright.

content.raw:
> I believe this agreement is only for materials that you give to OSRF. If you send an email to ROS users announcing a package that you maintain, then you don't need the "NOT A CONTRIBUTION" because you're discussing materials that you have not given to OSRF.

Yeah, the language defining "Material" could definitely be improved to be a little clearer. For example, I could definitely see this as being interpreted as any debian package hosted in the ROS release pipeline:

>>> "Material" means the work of authorship which is made available by Us to third parties. When this Agreement covers more than one software project, the Material means the work of authorship to which the Contribution was Submitted. After You Submit the Contribution, it may be included in the Material.

So that would mean that if you release a ROS package into the pipeline, it could be considered as "work of authorship which is made available by Us to third parties". Then if you submit any contributions to that package, this reads like OSRF gains copyright of it.

> We are also not in the business of going after copyright violations, or being draconian about copyright. We are concerned about protecting you and OSRF from other entities. It's easier to do this if OSRF maintains copyright, and the ability to guarantee proper licensing of our outputs.

Haha, yeah, I trust you guys. I know the intention isn't to become some oppressive software regime, I just like to make sure I understand what I'm signing (:
content.html:
I believe this agreement is only for materials that you give to OSRF. If you send an email to ROS users announcing a package that you maintain, then you don't need the "NOT A CONTRIBUTION" because you're discussing materials that you have not given to OSRF.

Yeah, the language defining "Material" could definitely be improved to be a little clearer. For example, I could definitely see this as being interpreted as any debian package hosted in the ROS release pipeline:

"Material" means the work of authorship which is made available by Us to third parties. When this Agreement covers more than one software project, the Material means the work of authorship to which the Contribution was Submitted. After You Submit the Contribution, it may be included in the Material.

So that would mean that if you release a ROS package into the pipeline, it could be considered as "work of authorship which is made available by Us to third parties". Then if you submit any contributions to that package, this reads like OSRF gains copyright of it.

We are also not in the business of going after copyright violations, or being draconian about copyright. We are concerned about protecting you and OSRF from other entities. It's easier to do this if OSRF maintains copyright, and the ability to guarantee proper licensing of our outputs.

Haha, yeah, I trust you guys. I know the intention isn't to become some oppressive software regime, I just like to make sure I understand what I'm signing (:

pull_request.title: Fix second-order dynamic library dependency (makes gazebo buildable with the GNU GoLD linker)

update.description:
Several functions from libavutil are used in libgazebo_common, but
only libavcodec was linked. While libavutil is a runtime libary dependency
of libavcodec, it does not become a direct runtime library dependency of
libgazebo_common. This means it will fail to link if LD_LIBRARY_PATH
is not set up properly or, more seriously, if using a linker which is
strict (like GNU GoLD).

tl;dr This enables Gazebo to be built with the GNU GoLD linker.
update.title: Fix second-order dynamic library dependency (makes gazebo buildable with the GNU GoLD linker)

content.raw:
Thanks!

I believe this agreement is only for materials that you give to OSRF. If you send an email to ROS users announcing a package that you maintain, then you don't need the "NOT A CONTRIBUTION" because you're discussing materials that you have not given to OSRF.

We are also not in the business of going after copyright violations, or being draconian about copyright. We are concerned about protecting you and OSRF from other entities. It's easier to do this if OSRF maintains copyright, and the ability to guarantee proper licensing of our outputs.
content.html:
Thanks!

I believe this agreement is only for materials that you give to OSRF. If you send an email to ROS users announcing a package that you maintain, then you don't need the "NOT A CONTRIBUTION" because you're discussing materials that you have not given to OSRF.

We are also not in the business of going after copyright violations, or being draconian about copyright. We are concerned about protecting you and OSRF from other entities. It's easier to do this if OSRF maintains copyright, and the ability to guarantee proper licensing of our outputs.

content.raw:
>Makes sense to me. I will assume that the additions of QT_LIBRARIES are in the same line.

Yeah, the QT stuff popped up when linking against gazebo from the plugins in `gazebo_ros_pkgs`.

>Jonathan Bohren I'm curious about what difference in compilation time have you get when using GoLD.

Not too much difference with Gazebo, but it saves a TON of time when I'm building Orocos stuff.

For Gazebo on my i7 laptop, `make -j4` gives:

* **gold:** `3935.56s user 191.35s system 380% cpu 18:05.45 total`
* **ld:** `4045.88s user 202.89s system 381% cpu 18:33.67 total`
content.html:
Makes sense to me. I will assume that the additions of QT_LIBRARIES are in the same line.

Yeah, the QT stuff popped up when linking against gazebo from the plugins in gazebo_ros_pkgs.

Jonathan Bohren I'm curious about what difference in compilation time have you get when using GoLD.

Not too much difference with Gazebo, but it saves a TON of time when I'm building Orocos stuff.

For Gazebo on my i7 laptop, make -j4 gives:

  • gold: 3935.56s user 191.35s system 380% cpu 18:05.45 total
  • ld: 4045.88s user 202.89s system 381% cpu 18:33.67 total

pull_request.title: Fix second-order dynamic library dependency (makes gazebo buildable with the GNU GoLD linker)

update.description:
Several functions from libavutil are used in libgazebo_common, but
only libavcodec was linked. While libavutil is a runtime libary dependency
of libavcodec, it does not become a direct runtime library dependency of
libgazebo_common. This means it will fail to link if LD_LIBRARY_PATH
is not set up properly or, more seriously, if using a linker which is
strict (like GNU GoLD).

tl;dr This enables Gazebo to be built with the GNU GoLD linker.
update.title: Fix second-order dynamic library dependency (makes gazebo buildable with the GNU GoLD linker)
